School of Environment and Energy Inner Mongolia University of Science & Technology Baotou Inner Mongolia 014010 China Preparation of low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts by Si and Mn modification and Si and Mn co-modification of CePO4 catalysts using mixed roasting and hydrothermal methods. XRD,BET,SEM and other characterisation tools were used to investigate the effect of Si and Mn modification on the catalyst structure. A series of different Si and Mn loadings and changes in catalyst denitrification performance, sulfur and water resistance after co-modification with Si and Mn were tested using NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and XPS, and the reaction pathways were investigated and the reaction mechanism of the catalysts was explored by FTIR detection in situ. The results show that CePO4-SiO2 catalyst at 250℃∼400℃, denitrification rate of about 90%; The optimum temperature for denitrification activity of the Mn/CePO4 catalyst was reduced, with a denitrification rate of 82% at 150℃; Mn/CePO4-SiO2 catalyst denitrification activity with significantly lower temperature and wider range. The denitrification rates of the catalysts were greater than 90% at 50℃∼300℃, with an optimum denitrification rate of 95 % at 150℃. The N2 selectivity of the catalyst is greater than 95 % in the low temperature range (below 200℃), good resistance to sulfur and water. The CePO4, SiO2 diffraction peaks on the surface of the sample decreased under the combined effect of Si and Mn. More acid sites appeared on the surface of the catalyst with elevated ratios of Ce3+ and adsorbed oxygen Oα, which promoted the catalyst's oxygen migration and conversion ability. After Si modification, the proportion of Mn4+ was significantly increased, which promoted the redox cycling of the catalyst in the low-temperature section. In situ IR results show that the catalyst follows both the Eley-Rideal mechanism and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism at 150℃. A variety of nitrate species produced by NO adsorption of the Si and Mn co-modified samples reacted rapidly with NH4 + species adsorbed at the Brønsted acid sites, which favoured the NH3-SCR reaction on the catalyst surface and improved the low-temperature denitrification efficiency. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CePO4 Si Mn modification NH3-SCR Denitrification mechanism Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction With the advancement of technology, global energy is still dominated by the burning of fossil fuels. Against the background of massive energy consumption and continuous pollution emissions, air pollution incidents occur from time to time [1]. NOX from combustion can cause serious environmental pollution problems, which not only pollutes the environment but also seriously endangers human health [2,3]. A common method for treating NOX is selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR), which uses NH3 as a reductant to selectively reduce NOX to N2 and H2O [4–6]. The core of this technology is the preparation of catalysts, and commercial catalysts have the disadvantages of being toxic, costly and having a high and narrow denitrification temperature range (between 300℃∼450℃). However, there are now many industries, such as ceramics, glass, and cement, that require flue gas temperatures below 300℃. Therefore, it is important to explore low-cost, low-pollution catalysts suitable for low denitrification temperatures. In recent years, research on catalysts has focused on both active components and carrier properties. It has been shown in our group [7], that the CePO4 as a carrier with good denitrification performance, it is an environmentally friendly catalyst. With an in-depth understanding of denitrification catalysts, Si modification was found to enhance the denitrification efficiency of the catalyst. Xiao et al. [8] doped cations (Zr4+, Al3+ and Si4+) into MnOX/CeO2 nanorods. They found that doping Zr4+, Al3+, and Si4+ in CeO2-NR can increase the specific surface area of the catalyst, and doing so facilitates the dispersion of MnOX species. Wei et al. [9] found that Ce interacts with Si to produce Ce-O-Si species in the prepared CeO2-SiO2 mixed oxides. Strong interactions generated by hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface can provide abundant surface acidic sites for NH3 adsorption. Gaseous NO reacts directly with adsorbed NH3 in the Eley-Rideal mechanism, thus accelerating the NH3-SCR reaction. After modification of the catalyst, it was found that the transition metal Mn had a good promotion effect on low temperature denitrification. Yuan and Jiang [10] prepared Mn-CeOX/CNTs catalysts, and it was found that the denitrification rate could reach 100 % when the reaction temperature was 160℃∼180℃. Leng et al. [11] prepared a Mn0.1Ce0.3TiOx catalyst that exhibited 100 % NO conversion between 175℃ and 400℃. This is because the Ce3++Mn4+→Ce4++Mn3+ reaction gives the catalyst good redox properties. Zhou and Ren [12] loaded the active components Mn and Fe oxides in nanopolyhedral form on the surface of CeO2-nps catalysts by impregnation method in order to improve the catalytic performance of CeO2-nps catalysts. The results of activity tests showed that the order of activity of these catalysts was Fe-Mn-Ce>Mn-Ce>Ce catalysts in the temperature range of 100°C to 300°C. Yang [13] et al. synthesized manganese oxide catalysts with different valence states (MnO2, Mn2O3, and Mn3O4) and investigated their role in NH3-SCR. In comparison, Mn2O3 and Mn3O4 showed almost the same NO conversion, while MnO2 showed better NO conversion over the whole temperature range. NH2 on the MnO2 surface reacts with gaseous NO to form NH2NO/NHNO, which decomposes to N2/N2O, respectively, while adsorbed monodentate nitrite combines with NH3 to form NH4NO2, which decomposes to N2. It was shown [7] that among the CePO4 catalysts prepared by varying the roasting temperature, the CePO4 after 500 °C roasting had some denitrification activity, but its temperature window was always maintained in the middle to high temperature band and its specific surface area was small. In order to further improve the denitrification efficiency of synthesized CePO4 and broaden its temperature window, the CePO4 catalysts were modified with Si, modified with Mn, and co-modified with Si and Mn in this study to investigate the changes in the performance of the catalysts and their mechanism of action. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Experimental materials The chemical reagents used in this experiment were cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3`6H2O), phosphoric acid (H3PO4), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), and silicon dioxide (SiO2), all of which were analytically pure and purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. The gases used in the experiment were ammonia (NH3) and nitric oxide (NO) produced by Xuzhou Special Gas Factory, and oxygen (O2) and nitrogen (N2) produced by Baotou Fuhua Gas Co. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst Firstly, weigh a certain amount of Ce(NO3)3 in deionised water and stir until dissolved, add H3PO4 solution according to the proportion, the solution will be hydrothermal for 2 h, roasting for 2 h can be obtained CePO4 powder, and then after 100 mesh sieving can be. Secondly, the sample CePO4-SiO2 was obtained by adding different proportions of SiO2 particles (Si loading of 10%, 15% and 20%) to the synthesised CePO4 and mixing the two powders by ball milling for 2 h and then roasting them in a muffle furnace for 2 h. Finally, a certain amount of CePO4 powder (Mn loading of 2%, 5%, 8%) was added to the aqueous solution of KMnO4, stirred magnetically for 2 h to mix thoroughly, and placed in a muffle furnace hydrothermal kettle at 120 °C for 12 h of hydrothermal heating to obtain the sample Mn/CePO4. In carrying out the preparation of Si and Mn co-modified CePO4 catalysts, the operation steps are approximately the same as those described above, in which it should be noted that the content of Si needs to be fixed when adjusting the ratio of Mn, and the content of Mn needs to be fixed when adjusting the ratio of Si. 2.3 Evaluation of the activity of the catalyst The schematic diagram of the experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1 . During the experiments of NH3-SCR denitrification reaction, the total gas flow rate was 100 mL/min, the volumetric airspeed is 20,000 h−1. where the concentrations of NO and NH3 are both 500 ppm, 6% O2 was passed and finally N2 was used as the equilibrium gas, the riser furnace was heated from room temperature to the experimental temperature at a ramp rate of 10℃/min, and online monitoring using Fourier infrared spectroscopy flue gas analyze. The value of NO was noted when the experimental temperature and atmosphere were in a steady state, denoted as (NO)in. Weigh 0.6 g of the sample, the samples were placed in quartz tubes, which were placed in a tube furnace for on-line measurement of flux variations of NH3 and NO using a Fourier infrared spectroscopy flue gas analyzer, reaction time of not less than 20 min for each temperature band. After the reaction is complete and the gas concentration profile has stabilised, the value is counted and recorded as (NO)out, with the outlet concentration in ppm. The conversion rate of NO is denoted by η and calculated using the following equation: (1) η = ( NO ) in − ( NO ) out ( NO ) in × 100 % The N2 selectivity of the catalyst needs to be monitored in real time while the catalyst is reacting in the tube furnace. Record the inlet concentration of NH3 at steady state temperature and atmosphere, noted as (NH3)in. The NH3-SCR reaction was started after placing the sample and waiting for the gas concentration profile to stabilise, the NH3 concentration at the outlet was recorded and noted as (NH3)out. The concentration of the by-product N2O produced during the reaction was recorded and noted as (N2O)out. (2) N 2 selectivity = ( 1 − 2 × ( N 2 O ) out ( NO ) in + ( N H 3 ) in − ( NO ) out − ( N H 3 ) out ) × 100 % 2.4 Catalyst characterization and equipment The characterisation and equipment used in this paper are as follows: For the physical phase analysis of the catalysts, the X-ray diffractometer used for the experiments was manufactured by Rigaku Corporation, Japan, model smartlab9kwx. To analyze the acid strength of the catalyst and to qualitatively analyze the amount of acid, the chemisorbent instrument used in the experiment was produced by Beijing Piande Electronic Technology Co. The analytical method was the continuous flow programmed ramping method, and the detector was a gold-plated TCD detector. For the infrared analysis of the catalyst, an infrared spectrometer from NETZSCH (Germany) was used. Catalyst surface element valence analyzes were performed using an EDX1800E instrument (XPS) from Tianrui Instruments Co. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic NH3-SCR performances The effects of different percentages of Si modification (Si modification: 0%, 10%, 15%, 20%) on the denitrification performance of CePO4 catalysts were explored, as shown in Fig. 2 . As can be seen from the figure, the denitrification activity was generally improved after adding different proportions of SiO2 compared with the unadded ones, and the denitrification rates were all kept above 85%. With the addition of 15 % SiO2, the maximum denitrification rate of 94 % was achieved at 250℃ and remained stable throughout the range of 250℃ to 450℃. The catalyst denitrification rate decreased with increasing SiO2 content, but remained at about 90%. This is because the presence of silica alters the surface morphology of cerium phosphate, increases the specific surface area of the catalyst, and reduces the crystallinity of CePO4 while increasing its dispersion, thus promoting the catalytic denitrification activity. With the further increase of SiO2 content, the denitrification rate decreased because the excess SiO2 powder blocked the pores of the catalyst, reduced the effective specific surface area and hindered the flow of reactive gases, which led to the decrease of denitrification rate. The effects of loading different proportions of Mn (Mn loading: 0%, 2%, 5%, 8%) on the denitrification performance of CePO4 catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . From the figure, it can be seen that the low temperature activity of the synthesised CePO4 is low, reaching 34.6 % at 150℃ and 51.8 % at 250℃. This is due to the fact that cerium phosphate exhibits a highly crystalline state at low temperatures, with a weak adsorption capacity for NH3, and the catalyst's redox capacity is poor at low temperatures, so that the NOX conversion is low. The low-temperature denitrification rate of the catalyst was improved after loading different contents of Mn, but the denitrification efficiency of the catalyst showed a tendency of increasing and then decreasing with the increase of the proportion of loaded Mn. The denitrification rate of the 5% Mn/CePO4 catalyst was much improved over that of CePO4, increasing from 34.6 to 82% at 150℃. This is due to the strong oxidation ability of Mn element, which promotes the transition between Ce3+ and Ce4+ in cerium phosphate during the hydrothermal process. Mn element possesses more valence states, and the cations of Mn and Ce are converted to each other, Mn4++Ce3+→Mn3++Ce4+, Mn3++Ce3+→Mn2++Ce4+, and these conversions enhance the redox performance of the catalysts. Performance and promoted the low-temperature denitrification activity of the catalyst. However, too much elemental Mn produces excess nitrate products which cover the surface of the catalyst, which can impede the catalyst's contact with the reaction gases NO and NH3, therefore reducing the catalytic reaction rate. The catalytic denitrification performance of the catalysts at a fixed ratio of Mn to adjust the content of Si is shown in Fig. 4(a) . The 5% Mn/CePO4 catalyst without Si modification achieved 82% denitrification at 150℃, and the low-temperature efficiency of the Si-modified catalyst was improved. When the amount of Si modification is 15%, the denitrification rate reaches 95%, and the activity temperature range becomes wider, the denitrification activity is above 90% in the range of 50℃∼300℃. It is shown that Si modification can enhance the low-temperature denitrification rate of the catalyst, because Si modification makes the active material of the catalyst more dispersed. After the co-modification effect of Mn and Si, the crystallinity of the catalyst was reduced and the active substances were more evenly dispersed. The redox ability of the catalyst at low temperature was enhanced, and the Mn and Si elements jointly promoted the NH3-SCR reaction of the catalyst in the low temperature range. As can be seen in the N2 selectivity comparison graph, the inhibition effect of different ratios of Si modification on the over-oxidation of the catalyst is small, and the reduction capacity of the catalyst is insufficient, and a large amount of N2O is still produced under the over-oxidation of Mn, which makes the N2 selectivity of the catalyst stabilised at about 80% at 400℃. The changes in denitrification performance of CePO4–15 %SiO2 catalysts modified with different ratios of Mn are shown in Fig. 4(b). From this figure, it can be seen that the unmodified Mn catalyst has a high denitrification efficiency in the middle and high temperature range, but has a poor denitrification rate at low temperatures, which reaches more than 30% at 150℃. However, after loading Mn on the carrier, the denitrification rate of the catalyst showed a tendency of increasing and then decreasing as the proportion of Mn increased. After modifying 5% Mn on the catalyst, the denitrification rate of 5% Mn/CePO4–15% SiO2 catalyst reached 95% at 150℃, which was about 60% higher than the original. It may be that the multivalent conversion effect of Mn improves the conversion between Ce3+ and Ce4+ and also increases the oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalyst, which enhances the redox capacity of CePO4-SiO2 at low temperatures and promotes its low-temperature activity. However, with the elevated amount of Mn modification, a large number of nitrate products generated from over-oxidation existed on the catalyst surface, which reduced the contact area of the reaction gases NO and NH3 with the catalyst surface, and therefore inhibited the catalytic denitrification rate. In the comparative N2 selectivity plot of the catalysts, it was found that the N2 selectivity of the catalyst CePO4-SiO2 was higher and remained above 98%. The N2 selectivity of the catalyst modified by Mn was reduced, and the N2 selectivity decreased with the increase of the Mn ratio, decreasing to 80% at 400℃. Due to the strong oxidising properties of Mn, it improves the oxidising performance of the catalyst while also over-oxidising the reaction gas NO to N2O, which leads to a decrease in N2 selectivity. As the Mn content increases, the oxidising capacity of the catalyst increases, leading to more N2O being produced and therefore reducing the N2 selectivity of the catalyst. 3.2 Effect of Si and Mn modification on catalyst surface structure 3.2.1 X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) In order to have a better understanding of the changes in the crystalline phase of the catalyst surface material after modification with different ratios of Si, the catalyst was analyzed by XRD, as shown in Fig. 5 . As can be seen from the figure, after mixed roasting, the substances in the catalyst are mainly in the form of SiO2 and CePO4. The diffraction peaks of SiO2 increase with the modification ratio of SiO2. However, the diffraction peaks of CePO4 at the 2θ positions of 29.2° and 31.5° show a tendency of decreasing and then increasing gradually. The half peak width of the cerium phosphate diffraction peak reaches its lowest at an increase in the content of SiO2 up to 15%. It is shown that at less than 15% SiO2, excess cerium phosphate cannot bind well to silica, and CePO4 remains heavily distributed on the catalyst surface in a highly crystalline state. And when the modification ratio exceeds 15%, the excess silica will cover the surface of the catalyst and cover or set on the surface of cerium phosphate to a certain extent, reducing the proportion of cerium phosphate, the active substance on the surface of the catalyst, and thus inhibiting the catalytic reaction. The crystalline phase changes of cerium phosphate carriers after loading with different ratios of Mn are shown in Fig. 6 . As can be seen from the figure, the Mn loading during the loading process is in the form of MnO2 when it is on the catalyst surface. However, the MnO2 independent diffraction peaks that do not appear in the figure are all composite peaks with CePO4 species. This indicates that when Mn is loaded on CePO4 carriers, the element Mn is more uniformly dispersed when it is loaded on the catalyst surface in the form of MnO2. The appearance of composite peaks in the XRD pattern indicates that the Mn element exists in an amorphous form when loaded, and this mode of existence is more conducive to the interaction of the modifying metal Mn with the active metal on the catalyst surface. which inhibited the growth of CePO4 crystal particles and increased its surface area while generating more oxygen vacancies to promote activation and enhance the denitrification rate. When the loading of Mn is 5%, the half peak width of the complex diffraction peak at the 20° position decreases significantly. The distribution of Mn elements on the carrier surface is more uniform, and the strong interactions between the active ions increase the oxygen vacancies, accelerate the process of the oxidation reaction of NO to NO2, and further synergize with the NH3 [14], so that the low-temperature catalytic denitrification reaction proceeds smoothly. In order to investigate the effect of Si and Mn co-modification on the crystalline phase structure of the catalysts, the catalysts with altered Si (a) and Mn (b) ratios were examined by XRD, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7 . Fig. 7(a) shows the XRD pattern of the catalyst after changing the Si ratio. From the figure, it can be seen that the height of the half peak width of the diffraction peak of SiO2 increases gradually with the increase of Si ratio. The height of the half peak width of the diffraction peaks of CePO4 at the positions of 14.4°, 19.9° and 29.0° decreases gradually. This indicates that the increase of Si content promotes the high dispersion of cerium phosphate, allowing more small particles of cerium phosphate to be produced on the catalyst surface and more active sites. No new diffraction peaks appeared on the catalyst surface after loading the same proportion of Mn elements, indicating that the amount of Mn modification was small and highly dispersed on the catalyst surface. Fig. 7(b) shows the XRD pattern of the catalyst after changing the Mn ratio, in which it was found that the substances on the surface of the catalyst were mainly CePO4, MnO2, and SiO2. This suggests that during Mn modification of the catalyst using KMnO4, the element Mn exists mainly in the form of MnO2. And there is only one diffraction peak that overlaps with CePO4 at the position 2θ of 29.2°, which is MnO2 in the amorphous state, suggesting that Mn is highly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst. The generation of Mn oxides was below the tested range of XRD, with few regions of accumulation and crystallisation. The height of the half peak width of the diffraction peaks of SiO2 showed a tendency of decreasing and then increasing with the increase of the amount of Mn modification. The lowest half peak width of the diffraction peak of SiO2 at 26.7° was observed at 5% Mn content. The broadening of the diffraction peak of MnO2 mixed with CePO4 at the 2θ position of 29.2° may be attributed to the entry of Mn ions into the lattice of CePO4, which promotes the multivalent transition between Ce and Mn, and the presence of Mn promotes the homogeneous dispersion of CePO4 on the surface of the catalysts, which inhibits the sintering agglomeration of SiO2. 3.2.2 Specific surface area and pore size analysis (BET) Fig. 8 (a)∼(d) show the isotherms curves of N2-adsorption desorption for CePO4, CePO4–15% SiO2, 5% Mn/CePO4, and 5% Mn/CePO4–15% SiO2 catalysts. From the figure, it can be seen that the isotherms curves of the four catalysts are concave, and there is no inflection point in the whole pressure range, and the amount of adsorbed gas is proportional to the partial pressure of the components, which belongs to the isotherms curve of adsorption-desorption of type III. This curve occurs because the interaction between the adsorbent and the adsorbate is weaker than the force of the adsorbate molecules on each other, and the heat of liquefaction of the adsorbent in the first layer is greater than the heat of adsorption, such that the adsorbent is difficult to adsorb in the pre-adsorption period; As the adsorption proceeds, there is an acceleration of adsorption and the number of adsorbed layers increases. When the pressure is increased, the adsorbed amount in the adsorption branch is smaller than the adsorbed amount in the desorption branch at the same relative pressure, and the curve shows a typical H3-type hysteresis loop. The trend of the curves shows that the higher the pressure, the more adsorption amount, indicating that all four catalysts have pores to be filled, and the CePO4 carrier has a more developed pore structure. The changes in specific surface area pore volume and average pore diameter of the catalytic samples before and after Si modification, Mn modification, and Si, Mn co-modification are shown in Table 1 . As can be seen from the table, the catalysts obtained after Si and Mn co-modification showed a greater improvement in specific surface area, pore diameter and pore volume than that of unloaded cerium phosphate, but compared with the catalysts modified with Si and Mn individually, the catalysts co-modified with Si and Mn showed a small specific surface area and a large pore diameter and pore volume. This may be due to the fact that too many modifying elements attached and adhered to the catalyst surface, which decreased the specific surface area of cerium phosphate, while the Si and Mn elements generated new large pores and cracks, increasing the proportion of large pores on the catalyst surface, which resulted in the overall pore volume and pore diameter of the catalyst becoming larger. The loose and porous surface morphology promotes the rapid circulation of the reaction gases NH3 and NO, accelerates the conversion of gas components on the catalyst surface, and improves the catalytic reaction rate. 3.2.3 Scanning electron microscopy, energy spectroscopy (SEM,EDS) Fig. 9 shows the SEM morphology and EDS energy spectrum of 5%Mn/CePO4 -15%SiO2 catalyst. As can be seen in the figure, the catalyst is an irregular rod-like structure Si and Mn elements are adhered to CePO4 in an aggregated, covered form. The morphology is distinctly dense, with rods of varying lengths, split and fragmented, with a more developed pore structure, consistent with the analysis of the BET results. From the EDS spectra, it can be seen that the loading of Si and Mn elements is more successful, and each element is uniformly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst, so more reactive gases can be adsorbed to improve the catalytic activity. 3.3 Effect of Si and Mn modification on catalyst surface properties 3.3.1 Ability to adsorb NH3 on the catalyst surface (NH3-TPD) The effect of different contents of Si modification on the ammonia adsorption capacity of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 10(a) . As can be seen from the figure, the temperature of the desorption peak of NH4 + ions on the weak acid sites was 196°C in the temperature range of 100∼300°C for the catalyst after the addition of 10% SiO2, and the temperature of the desorption peak was reduced to 183°C with the increase of the Si content, which indicated that the increase of the proportion of SiO2 could effectively promote the adsorption of NH3 at lower temperatures and the NH3-SCR reaction at low temperatures. The adsorption and desorption of ammonia was weaker for the catalyst with 10% added SiO2 in the temperature range of 300°C∼800°C, while the peak area of ammonia desorption showed a tendency of increasing and then decreasing when increasing the Si ratio. The area of the ammonia desorption peak was largest when 15% SiO2 was added to the catalyst, probably because the specific surface area of the catalyst was largest at this ratio, exposing a greater number of acid sites. And the small particle morphology of Si and Ce on the catalyst surface can provide more acid sites, which makes the catalyst more capable of ammonia adsorption. And when the Si ratio was further increased, the excessive SiO2 molecules scattered on the catalyst surface covered the catalyst surface, which led to the decrease of ammonia adsorption capacity and the inhibition of ammonia adsorption and desorption cycle on the catalyst surface. A comparison of NH3-TPD after loading different percentages of Mn is shown in Fig. 10(b). A small desorption peak appeared in the catalyst at around 100°C for Mn loading of 2% and 8% [15], which is attributed to the desorption peak of NH3 in the physically desorbed state. In the temperature interval from 100°C to 300°C, all three samples produced a strong desorption peak, which was attributed to the desorption peak produced by the desorption of ionic NH4 + at the weakly acidic site. Comparison revealed that the samples with 2% and 5% Mn loading yielded a larger area of desorption peaks, indicating the presence of a higher number of weak acid sites on the surface of the samples. In the presence of elemental manganese, the crystal structure of CePO4 is disrupted, exposing more phosphate and thus providing good conditions for the adsorption and transformation of ammonia species on a larger surface area basis. The samples with 5% and 8% Mn loading also showed a detachment peak near 350℃, which was attributed to a mixture of detachment peaks at the strongly acidic and moderately acidic sites. The samples in the temperature range of 300℃ to 700℃ all produced a stable detachment peak, which was attributed to the detachment peak formed by the desorption of molecular state NH3 at the strongly acidic site. The peak temperature of this desorption peak shifted to lower temperatures after increasing the proportion of Mn loading, and the temperature of this desorption peak was 492℃ at a Mn proportion of 5%, and the increase in the distance shifted to lower temperatures suggests that increasing the proportion of Mn allows the samples to function in the low-temperature range. The charge enriched on the surface of Ce atoms after loading Mn moves toward Mn atoms, which makes the electron cloud density around Ce atoms decrease, and the lack of electricity of Ce provides weak acid sites [16], which enhances the NH3 adsorption in the low-temperature section of the catalyst and promotes the low-temperature activity. In order to investigate the effect of Si and Mn co-modification on the catalyst's ability to adsorb NH3, the NH3-TPD assay was carried out on the adjusted ratios of the two substances, respectively, as shown in Fig. 11 . When the ratio of Mn was fixed to adjust the content of Si, as shown in Fig. 11(a), the NH3 detachment peaks in the range of 100°C∼300°C reached the maximum area when the content of Si was 15%, and the detachment peaks in this range were attributed to the detachment peaks of NH4 + on the weak acidic sites, which indicated that the number of weak acidic sites on the surface of cerium phosphate was higher at this ratio and the peak temperature of the detachment peaks was shifted to the low temperature at this ratio to increase the activation energy of the weak acidic sites at the low temperature to promote the denitrification at low temperatures. The 15% SiO2 of the sample at 350°C was also accompanied by a mixed desorption peak of strong and medium acidic sites, which further enhanced the low-temperature activity. And the difference in the area of the desorption peaks of different proportions of SiO2 in the temperature range from 300°C to 800°C is small, indicating that the modification of SiO2 has a small effect on the number of acidic sites on the catalyst surface. Fixing the proportion of Si adjusted the content of Mn as shown in Fig. 11(b). The area of the desorption peak was gradually smaller with the increase of the Mn ratio, and the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for NH3 was reduced, which might be due to the high content of modifiers on the surface of the catalyst under the co-modification of Si and Mn, whereas the further increase of the Mn ratio would be excessively attached to the surface of the catalyst, which would lower the specific surface area of the catalyst, reduce the number of acidic sites on the surface of the catalyst, and inhibit the adsorption of NH3. 3.3.2 Catalyst surface redox properties (H2-TPR) The effect of different ratios of Si modification on the redox capacity of the catalysts is shown in Fig. 12(a) . As can be seen from the figure, the catalyst with 10% SiO2 addition shows a reduction peak at 592℃, which is the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ [17]. As the proportion of Si increases, the peak temperature of the reduction peak moves towards higher temperatures. It may be that SiO2 has a poor redox capacity, the more Si is added to the same mass of catalyst, the proportion of cerium phosphate with high reducing properties decreases, and the smaller amount of the active component enhances the difficulty of the catalyst's low-temperature redox. The addition of 15% SiO2 increased the peak area of the reduction peak. It is possible that the addition of Si reduces the crystallinity of cerium phosphate, and more CePO4 in the weakly crystalline state appears on the surface, promoting the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+. At the same time, more cracks and gaps are generated on the surface of the catalyst, and more oxygen voids and oxygen defects are generated while the specific surface area is increased, generating more oxygen vacancies to promote the valence transformation of Ce elements and the migration of oxygen atoms. And after further increasing the proportion of Si, the area of the catalyst reduction peak was reduced, and the surface of the active component was occupied by SiO2, which reduced the number of effective oxygen vacancies, decreased the generation of reduction products, and inhibited the redox cycle. The effect of different ratios of Mn loading on the redox capacity of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 12(b). The catalyst with 2% Mn loading was found to contain a reduction peak at 423℃, which was attributed to the reduction of Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 [18,19]. The reduction peak at 587℃ is attributed to Mn2O3 to MnO [20]. The peak areas of the loaded catalysts were enhanced more relative to the unloaded CePO4. This suggests that the loading of Mn can improve the redox capacity of the catalyst surface, produce more reducing substances, and promote the conversion of NO to NO2. As the proportion of Mn loading increased, the peak temperature of the catalyst reduction peak shifted to a lower temperature and the peak area gradually increased. This may be due to the fact that the proportion of oxidant contained in the catalyst increases as the Mn content increases. The presence of a large amount of oxidant and the multivalent state of elemental Mn accelerated the conversion between Ce4+ and Ce3+ and increased the content of catalyst oxygen vacancies. Therefore, increasing the rate of oxygen migration and conversion in the low-temperature section leads to the enhancement of the redox performance of the catalyst at low temperature, which contributes to the shift of the optimal activity temperature of the catalyst after Mn loading towards low temperature. In order to investigate the effect of Si and Mn co-modification on the redox properties of the catalysts, the three catalysts were subjected to H2-TPR assay, as shown in Fig. 13 . Fig. 13(a) shows the H2-TPR profile of the catalyst with fixed proportion of Mn to adjust the content of Si. The reduction peaks of the catalysts shifted the peak temperature to lower temperatures with increasing Si ratio, but the peak area decreased gradually. It may be that the increase of Si improves the dispersion of cerium phosphate, and the low binding energy Ce ions uniformly dispersed on the catalyst surface are highly susceptible to electron transfer with Mn ions, generating a large number of oxygen vacancies to promote the redox of the catalyst. Increasing the mass ratio of SiO2 also decreases the mass ratio of cerium phosphate. So, the content of cerium phosphate decreases with the same mass of catalyst, the content of Ce that synergises with Mn decreases, and the substances that can undergo redox decrease, which in turn decreases the area of the reduction peaks. Fig. 13(b) shows the H2-TPR profile of the catalyst with fixed proportion of Si increasing the content of Mn. The area of catalyst reduction peaks increased with the increase of Mn ratio. It indicates that the redox capacity of the active substances on the catalyst surface is enhanced by increasing the Mn ratio, which promotes the low-temperature oxidation of the catalyst, generates more reduction products and increases the peak area. 3.3.3 Catalyst surface electron transfer capacity (XPS) In order to further understand the state of elemental assignment on the catalyst surface before and after Si modification, the valence distribution and electron transfer status of different elements were explored. The synthesized CePO4 and CePO4–15% SiO2 were analyzed by XPS, as shown in Fig. 14 . Fig. 14(a) shows the 3d spectrum of elemental Ce. From the figure, it can be seen that the Ce 3d spectrum contains eight characteristic peaks, of which u(900.8 eV), u″(907.5 eV), u″′(916.5 eV), v(882.3 eV), v″(888.9 eV), v″′(898.4 eV) are attributed to the characteristic peaks of Ce4+ and u′(903.8 eV), v′(884.7 eV) are attributed to the characteristic peaks of Ce3+ [21,22]. Ce3+ in CePO4 has a high proportion in the valence state of Ce, and the unsaturated chemical energy exhibited by low valence Ce can promote the adsorption of the reactive gas NH3 and accelerate the oxidation of NO to NO2, thus increasing the reaction rate. In contrast, Ce4+ is higher in the valence state of Ce after Si modification. This suggests that the large amount of small-sized CePO4 with low crystallinity appearing on the surface of the catalyst after Si modification and changing the valence distribution of the Ce element makes part of Ce3+ converted to Ce4+, leading to charge imbalance and unsaturation of the chemical bond, in the process creating more oxygen vacancies as a way to promote the redox cycle [23]. This conclusion can be verified from the XRD patterns and H2-TPR. Comparison revealed that the characteristic peaks at u′, u, and v″′ were shifted to high binding energies after Si modification, while the characteristic peaks at v″ and v′ were shifted to low binding energies. This suggests that Ce and Si are roasted at high temperatures to reduce the binding energy of the original cerium phosphate and produce more unsaturated bonds to reduce the stability of the catalyst, increase oxygen vacancies, and promote oxygen migration. The state of the oxygen element reflects the content of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalyst, and an increase in the number of oxygen vacancies can improve the migration and conversion rate, provide more reaction sites for NO oxidation of NO2, and accelerate the redox cycle. Fig. 14(b) shows the 1s spectrogram of elemental O. The characteristic peaks near 531.3∼531.9 eV are attributed to the peaks of adsorbed oxygen Oα on the catalyst surface. This is due to adsorbed oxygen due to oxygen vacancies, and Oβ promotes the oxidation of NO to NO2 [24]. The characteristic peaks near 529.3∼530.0 eV are attributed to the peaks of the catalyst lattice oxygen Oβ [25], which is oxygen in the crystal structure. Adsorbed oxygen is generally considered to be more unstable in comparison and more susceptible to oxygen molecule migration and transformation. The proportion of adsorbed oxygen Oα on the surface of the catalyst increased after Si modification, indicating that the interstices and cracks on the surface of the catalyst increased after Si doping, and more oxygen vacancies were generated on the catalytic surface after the increase of the surface area, and more reactive oxygen species existed to promote the migratory activation of oxygen molecules to promote the redox cycling, and the corresponding conclusions can also be obtained in H2-TPR. In order to investigate the effect of Si modification on the P element in cerium phosphate, the fugacity state of the P element in the catalyst before and after Si modification was analyzed by XPS, as shown in Fig. 14(c). The peaks in the spectrum of P can be assigned to the characteristic peak of P4O10(134.0 eV) and the characteristic peak PO3 - of (133.0 eV) [26]. In both catalysts P element is mainly present in the form of P4O10, accounting for more than 50%, indicating that P element is mainly involved in the crystal structure of CePO4, with a small amount in the form of phosphate. The silica modification increased the proportion of PO3 - characteristic peak presence form, destabilized the cerium phosphate structure and exposed more phosphoric acid in ionic form, leading to an increase in the number of Brønsted acidic sites on the surface of the catalyst and an increase in the adsorption of NH3 on the surface of the catalyst, which in turn facilitated the catalytic reaction. The specific gravity of the peak areas of the elements (Ce, O, P) of the samples before and after Si modification is shown in Table 2 . In order to investigate the effect of loading Mn on the electron transfer situation of the catalytic catalysts, the catalysts with the best denitrification rate after loading cerium phosphate and Mn were analyzed by XPS detection as shown in Fig. 15 . Fig. 15(a) shows the XPS spectrum of Ce 3d. The Ce 3d spectrum contains eight characteristic peaks, of which u(900.8 eV), u″(907.5 eV), u″′(916.5 eV), v(882.3 eV), v″(888.9 eV), v″′(898.4 eV) characteristic peaks attributed to Ce4+, u′(903.8 eV), v′(884.7 eV) characteristic peaks attributed to Ce3+ [21,22]. Upon comparison, it was found that 5% loading of cerium phosphate with Mn resulted in a decrease in the proportion of Ce3+ and an increase in the content of Ce4+ on the catalyst surface, indicating that loading of Mn resulted in an increase in the conversion of Ce3+ to Ce4+. The characteristic peaks of u″, u′, u, and v″′ in the figure are shifted to low binding energies, and the corresponding binding energies of Ce3+ and Ce4+are reduced. It was shown that the addition of manganese destroyed the original stable crystalline structure of cerium phosphate. It increased the surface area and oxidizing ability of the catalyst, promoted the ability of the carrier to oxidize NO, and improved the removal rate of NOX. In Fig. 15(b), the characteristic peaks near 531.3∼531.9 eV are the characteristic peaks of surface adsorbed oxygen Oα due to the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, and the characteristic peaks near 529.3∼530.0 eV are the characteristic peaks of lattice oxygen Oβ inside the catalyst lattice [25]. From the figure, it can be found that the characteristic peaks of lattice oxygen Oβ are shifted to the direction of low binding energy after Mn loading, and the ratio of lattice oxygen Oβ in the state of oxygen presence within the catalyst increases, indicating an increase in the content of lattice oxygen. The decrease in binding energy and the increase in the ratio of lattice oxygen can indicate that the structure of CePO4 in the samples changed after Mn loading, which made the binding energy of metal cation Ce and lattice oxygen in cerium phosphate decrease, and it is easier to be converted under low temperature conditions, promoting the low-temperature catalytic denitrification rate. In Fig. 15(c), the fugacity state of elemental P before and after loading Mn has been analyzed by XPS, and the peaks in the spectrum of P can be assigned to the characteristic peaks of P4O10 (134.0 eV) and the characteristic peak of PO3 - (133.0 eV) [26]. In the synthesized CePO4 elemental P is present in more than 50 % of P4O10, and a small amount is present in the form of phosphate and provides acidic sites for the catalyst. After modification with Mn, the ratio of P4O10 in the structure decreases and the ratio of PO3 - increases. This suggests that after modification with Mn, some of the Ce in the cerium phosphate structure is displaced and most of the exposed P-O bonds are present in the form of phosphoric acid. The increase in the number of acid sites on the catalyst surface promotes the adsorption and conversion of active gas NH3, consistent with the findings of NH3-TPD. Fig. 15(d) shows the 2p spectra of elemental Mn in the catalyst 5%Mn/CePO4. As can be seen from the figure, the 2p orbitals of the Mn element can be mainly divided into two characteristic peaks, Mn 2p1/2 (653.0 eV) and Mn 2p3/2 (641.0 eV) [27]. The 2p3/2 characteristic peak of Mn can be subdivided into three smaller peaks, which are Mn2+ (641.0∼641.3 eV), Mn3+ (642.0∼642.6 eV), and Mn4+ (644.0∼644.7 eV) [28]. A larger proportion of Mn3+was found in the Mn 2p3/2 characteristic peaks, indicating that Mn3+ is mainly present as Mn3+ on the catalyst surface. Due to the more valence forms of Mn, the transitions between different valence states are more frequent, and it is easier to transfer the electrons with Ce on the surface of the catalyst to form the composite structure, which contributes to the improvement of the catalyst performance. The specific gravity of the peak areas of the elements (Ce, O, P) of the samples before and after Mn modification is shown in Table 3 . To further investigate the difference in electron transfer of catalyst elements between Si and Mn co-modification and single Si modification and single Mn modification, comparative XPS analysis was carried out, as shown in Fig. 16 . Fig. 16(a) shows the XPS pattern of Ce 3d, where u(900.8 eV), u″(907.5 eV), u″′(916.5 eV), v(882.3 eV), v″(888.9 eV), v″′(898.4 eV) are attributed to the characteristic peaks of Ce4+ and u′(903.8 eV), v′(884.7 eV) are attributed to the characteristic peaks of Ce3+ [21,22]. Upon comparison, it was found that the proportion of Ce3+ on the catalyst surface was significantly increased after the co-modification of Si and Mn, and a large amount of CePO4 in the weakly crystalline state was exposed on the catalyst surface under the dispersion of Si. Electron transfer between surface Ce atoms and Mn atoms in turn promotes redox, leading to an increase in the concentration of Ce3+ and the creation of more unsaturated bonds and oxygen vacancies [29], which promotes the adsorption and oxidation of NO. The XPS pattern of O 1 s in the catalyst after co-modification with Si and Mn is shown in Fig. 16(b). The characteristic peaks near 531.3∼531.9 eV are attributed to the peaks of adsorbed oxygen Oα on the catalyst surface, which is adsorbed oxygen due to oxygen vacancies. While the characteristic peaks near 529.3∼530.0 eV are attributed to the peaks of catalyst lattice oxygen Oβ, which is oxygen in the crystal structure [25]. The proportion of adsorbed oxygen Oα on the catalyst surface increases, the amount of lattice oxygen Oβ decreases, and oxygen vacancies accompany Ce3+. Oxygen vacancies appear rapidly after Ce3+ formation to maintain charge balance, and oxygen molecules tend to combine with single electrons in the oxygen vacancies to form a variety of oxygen adsorption species. The redox properties of the catalyst were enhanced by the increase in the number of oxygen vacancies, the ability to store and release oxygen and the activity of oxygen species were improved, and adsorbed oxygen was more readily generated at low temperatures, which shifted the temperature interval of catalytic denitrification toward low temperatures and promoted low-temperature activity. The weights of the peak areas of the elements (Ce, O, P) in the samples before and after co-modification of Si and Mn are listed in Table 4. The XPS profile of P 2p is shown in Fig. 16(c), and the peaks in the spectrum of P can be assigned to the characteristic peaks of P4O10 (134.0 eV) and the characteristic peak of PO3 -(133.0 eV) [26]. This indicates that the element P always appears as P4O10 and PO3 - on the catalyst surface. After the co-modification of Si and Mn, the proportion of PO3 - is further increased, the Ce atom in the cerium phosphate structure is transferred in the form of Ce3+, and the exposed P-O bond exists on the catalyst surface in the form of PO3 -. As a result, more Brønsted acidic sites were generated on the catalyst surface to enhance the adsorption of alkaline gas NH3 by the catalyst in the low-temperature section and to increase the cycle rate of low-temperature adsorption and desorption. The XPS profile of Mn 2p is shown in Fig. 16(d). The co-modification of Si and Mn has some changes in the valence ratios of the Mn elements compared to the catalysts with single Mn modification. The proportion of Mn4+ is elevated under co-modification, while Mn4+ is the most active substance in the Mn valence state in the catalytic SCR reaction [30]. The presence of high valence Mn can be reduced to more valence Mn ions, which induces more substances on the catalyst surface to be oxidized, and enhances the oxidation ability of the catalyst for NO. 3.3.4 Sulfur and water resistance testing During the catalytic reaction, the presence of SO2 and water vapor in the atmosphere can poison and deactivate the catalyst. SO2 not only reacts with NH3, H2O, and O2, but also adheres to the catalyst surface, which leads to a decrease in catalytic activity, and water vapor competes with NH3 and NO for adsorption [31–33]. In order to explore the toxicity resistance of the catalysts, the 5% Mn/CePO4–15% SiO2 catalysts were subjected to sulfur and water resistance experiments, and the results are shown in Fig. 17 . From the activity test experiments, it can be seen that the catalyst possesses good denitrification activity in the range of 100℃∼400℃, so the present experiments were also carried out in the range of 100℃∼400℃. Not only that, the catalyst reached the best denitrification activity (95%) at 150℃, so the catalyst was also tested for sulfur and water resistance at 150℃ for 10 h. As can be seen in the figure, the NOX conversion decreased by about 10% after the catalyst was fed with 5% vol H2O+50 ppm SO2 in the range of 100℃ to 400℃, but the overall trend remained the same. There was some increase in activity after cutting off the passage of H2O and SO2, but it did not recover the initial values. At the optimal denitrification temperature of 150℃, the passage of H2O and SO2 can be found that the activity of the catalyst decreases with the increase of time, and decreased by about 30 % at 8 h, and the activity gradually recovered after cutting off the passage of H2O and SO2. Which may be due to the fact that Mnn+ has good redox properties and improves the surface acidity and active sites of the catalyst, so it is less affected by H2O and SO2. 3.4 In situ infrared The variation of NH3 adsorption with time on the catalyst co-modified by Si and Mn is shown in Fig. 18(a) . Infrared adsorption experiments were carried out using the catalyst with the best ratio under co-modification, 5% Mn/CePO4–15% SiO2, at the temperature of 150℃, the temperature at which the denitrification rate was the highest. Just after the passage of 5 min of NH3 gas, the catalyst surface showed a large characteristic peak of the intermediate species -NH2 produced by the dehydrogenation of NH3 on the Brønsted acid site at 1518 cm−1 [34]. The characteristic peak of NH3 species with a smaller Lewis acidic site occurs at 1298 cm−1 [35]. Suggests that the catalyst adsorbs species mainly by the Brønsted acidic site when it is first passed into NH3. The IR adsorption peak at the Lewis acidic site at 1298 cm−1 was enhanced after the continued passage of NH3, and a large number of Lewis acidic sites on the catalyst surface functioned to adsorb NH3. Further passage of NH3 resulted in a weakening of the characteristic peak at the Lewis acid site at 1298 cm−1, a diminishing of the characteristic peak of NH3 species at the Lewis acid site at 1625 cm−1, and the emergence of the characteristic peaks of -NH2 at the Brønsted acid site at 1518 cm−1 and the characteristic peak of NH4 + species at the Brønsted acid site at 1448 cm−1 [36], and the larger NH4 + species characteristic peaks at the Brønsted acid sites at 1540cm−1 and 1455 cm−1. This suggests that the main acting acid sites on the catalyst surface show a shift from Brønsted acid sites to Lewis acidic sites to Brønsted acid sites as the NH3 flux time is lengthened. The characteristic peak of Brønsted acid site at 1455 cm−1 was weakened more after 30 min of N2 administration, showing the instability of the acid site, while the characteristic peak of Lewis acid site at 1298 cm−1 was weakened to a lesser extent, and the Lewis acidic site on the surface of the catalyst was more stable. The samples co-modified by Si and Mn showed the characteristics of increased content of B acid sites and improved stability of L acid sites, which enhanced the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for NH3 and improved the catalytic performance under the joint action of Si and Mn. The variation of the process of NO+O2 adsorption at 150℃ for the catalyst 5%Mn/CePO4–15%SiO2 co-modified by Si and Mn is shown in Fig. 18(b). A large number of sTable 1600 cm−1 IR absorption peaks appeared on the catalyst surface, which corresponded to NO2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and the large amount of NO2 contributed to the rapid NH3-SCR reaction of the catalyst. The flux of NO+O2 was accompanied by the appearance of an absorption peak at 1121cm−1 attributed to even secondary nitrate [-(N2O2)2−] species and disappeared at 40 min [34]. The 1310cm−1 absorption peak of the intermediate product nitro-like groups also appeared when NO+O2 was passed for 10 min. After a 30 min blowdown with N2, only NO2 at 1600cm−1 [37] and monodentate nitrate at 1110 cm−1 remained on the surface. The catalyst co-modified with Si and Mn adsorbed a large amount of NO2, which accelerated the NH3-SCR reaction of the catalyst due to the strong oxidizing property of NO2 and the large amount of unstable intermediate ammonium nitrite, which decomposed rapidly into N2, produced during the reaction of NO2 with NH3. The temperature dependence of the adsorption capacity of the catalyst 5%Mn/CePO4–15%SiO2 co-modified by Si and Mn for NH3 from 50℃ to 300℃ is shown in Fig. 19(a) . At 50℃, a symmetric deformation vibrational peak 1521 cm−1 on the Brønsted acidic site and an absorption peak 1261 cm−1 of NH3 species on the Lewis acidic site appeared on the catalyst surface. After continuing to increase the temperature, the two peaks weakened and disappeared, and there appeared a large number of vibrational peaks 1358 cm−1 for the NH bond [38] of the B-acid site and 1676 cm−1 for the symmetric deformation of the NH4 + species in the B-acid site as well as 1210 cm−1 for the absorption peak of the liganded NH3 on the l-acidic site [39], which indicated that the surface of the catalyst possessed a large number of B-acidic sites and l-acidic sites in this temperature band. When the temperature reached 300°C, the NH4 + absorption peak at the B acid site at 1660 cm−1 and the absorption peak of -NH2 species formed at the L acid site at 1493 cm−1 still appeared in large quantities. It indicates that under the co-modification of Si and Mn, the catalyst surface in the middle and low temperature segments contains more Brønsted acidic sites and Lewis acidicsites, which makes the catalyst in the middle and low temperature segments more capable of adsorbing and transforming NH3, and thus promotes the denitrification activity in the middle and low temperatures. The adsorption capacity of the Si and Mn co-modified catalyst 5%Mn/CePO4- 15%SiO2 for NO+O2 at 50℃∼300℃ is shown in Fig. 19(b). At 50℃, the catalyst showed absorption peaks of bidentate nitrate at 1580 cm−1 [40] and intermediate product -NO3 species at 1320 cm−1. While the -NO3 species disappeared on the catalyst surface when warming up to 100℃, the characteristic peak area of bidentate nitrate became larger and was accompanied by an absorption peak of NO2 species appearing at 1698cm−1. At this point the catalyst surface bidentate nitrate species are thermally stable and provide the main active site for the reaction. At 150℃, the bidentate nitrate participates in the reaction and disappears, and a large absorption peak of monodentate nitrate appears at 1442 cm−1 on the catalyst surface. However, the absorption peaks of bidentate nitrate at 1550 cm−1 and 1141 cm−1 at 200℃ were weak. While the denitrification activity is higher at this time, a large number of nitro groups on the surface bind to Cen+ and participate in the reaction at 200℃, and the Ce group activity becomes weaker when it reaches 250℃, the absorption peak of bidentate nitrate at 1550 cm−1 increases. Upon warming to 300℃, the absorption peaks of bidentate and monodentate nitrate disappeared, and the absorption peak of NO2 species at 1698 cm−1 remained on the surface. It can be seen that the highly reactive species produced in the adsorption of NO+O2 by the catalysts co-modified with Si and Mn during the warming process are mainly bidentate and monodentate nitrates. The IR profile of Si, Mn co-modified catalyst 5%Mn/CePO4–15%SiO2 after NH3 pretreatment with NO+O2 passed at 150℃ is shown in Fig. 20(a) . After 1 h of NH3 pretreatment, the catalyst surface showed absorption peaks of 1485 cm−1 for NH4 + species on the B-acidic site and 1220 cm−1 for NH3 species on the Lewis acidic site. After 30 min of N2 purge, NO+O2 was passed for 5 min and IR absorption peaks appeared at 1619 cm−1, 1450 cm−1, 1358 cm−1, and 1183 cm−1. The absorption peaks at 1619 cm−1 and 1183 cm−1 belong to bridged nitrate [41]. At 1450 cm−1 is the absorption peak of intermediate product -NO2. At 1358 cm−1 is attributed to monodentate nitrite. The nitrate absorption peak did not disappear completely after 5 min, indicating that a portion of the NH3 species on the catalyst surface reacted rapidly, following the Eley-Rideal mechanism. Adsorption peaks of monodentate nitrate at 1246 cm−1 [42], absorption peaks of intermediate-NO3 species at 1300 cm−1 and bridging nitrate at 1380 cm−1 also appeared after continued passage of NO+O2. At this time, the peak of nitrate decreases in peak intensity along with the increase of time, indicating that the nitrate species on the surface of the catalyst undergoes a SCR reaction with the adsorbed NH3 species, following the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. At 20 min, the nitrate absorption peaks at 1619 cm−1, 1450 cm−1 and 1380cm−1 disappeared. And at 30 min, the nitrate absorption peaks appeared again, and the peak intensity increased with the increase of time. It indicated that the NH3 species adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst had been completely consumed at this time. The catalyst in turn continues to adsorb NO+O2, generating new nitrate active sites waiting for a new NH3-SCR reaction. Co-modification of Si and Mn resulted in a faster NH3-SCR reaction rate and higher cyclic regeneration capacity of the active sites, which led to a faster degradation rate of NOX by the catalyst. The variation of NH3 adsorption with time for Si, Mn co-modified catalyst 5%Mn/CePO4–15%SiO2 after NO+O2 preadsorption at 150℃ for 1 h after the passage of NO+O2 is shown in Fig. 20(b). After the passage of 1 h of NO+O2, the absorption peak of bidentate nitrate appeared at 1560 cm−1 and the peak area was large, indicating that the NOX adsorbed by the catalyst mainly existed in the form of bidentate nitrate, which was consistent with the experimental results of NO+O2 adsorption by the catalyst in the previous period. After N2 rinsing of the experimental bench for 30 min and continued passage of NH3, the absorption peaks of bidentate nitrate disappeared, and absorption peaks of NH4 + species on the B-acidic site at 1410 cm−1 and NH3 species attributed to the l-acidic site at 1270 cm−1 and 1152 cm−1 appeared, suggesting that bidentate nitrate reacts with either NH3 species or NH4 + species, following the L-H mechanism. After continued passage of NH3, absorption peaks of Brønsted acidic sites at 1455 cm−1 and 1390 cm−1 as well as absorption peaks of Lewis acidicsites located at 1270 cm−1, 1152 cm−1, and 1150 cm−1 appeared. The Brønsted acidic site located at 1455 cm−1 disappeared at 20 min and reappeared in large numbers at 30 min. This suggests that nitrate species on the catalyst surface are still present at 20 min, reacting with the NH4 + species at the Brønsted acidic sites. While the nitrate on the catalyst surface was depleted at 30 min, a large number of acid sites were generated to continue the adsorption of NH3 with the passage of NH3 to the catalyst surface. The bidentate nitrate on the catalyst surface under the co-modification of Si and Mn reacted rapidly with the Brønsted acidic and Lewis acidicsites, and the adsorbed nitrate species were already consumed at 30 min. The catalyst reaction path is shown in Fig. 21 . The 5%Mn/CePO4–15%SiO2 catalyst at 150℃ followed both the Eley-Rideal mechanism and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. The main species reacting in the Eley-Rideal mechanism are gaseous NO with NH4 + species on the Brønsted acidic site, and the products are N2 and H2O. The hypothesized reaction paths are as follows: (9) N H 3 ( g ) → NH 4 + ( a ) ( Br ø nsted ) (10) 2 M n + = O + 2 NO + O 2 → 2 M n − 1 + − O − N O 2 (11) 2 □ − NH 4 + + M n − 1 + − O − N O 2 → 2 ( □ − NH 4 + ) − N O 2 − O − M n − 1 + (12) 2 ( 2 ( □ − NH 4 + ) N O 2 − O − M n − 1 + ) O 2 → 4 □ − H + 2 M n + = O + 3 N 2 + 6 H 2 O 4 Conclusion In order to enable the catalyst to achieve both improved denitrification performance and a shift in the temperature window to lower temperatures. In this paper, the synthesized CePO4 was modified with Si and Mn using hybrid roasting and hydrothermal methods. The effects of Si and Mn mono-modification and co-modification on the performance of the catalysts were explored by adjusting the ratio. The conclusions of the experiment are as follows: (1) The introduction of Si and Mn has a significant effect on the denitrification performance of the catalyst, and the catalyst with 5% Mn and 15% SiO2 loading has the best denitrification performance, with a denitrification rate of 95% at 150℃, a denitrification rate of more than 90% in the temperature range of 50℃∼300℃, N2 selectivity of more than 80%, and a good sulphur and water resistance of the catalyst in the corresponding temperature range. (2) The CePO4 and SiO2 diffraction peaks on the sample surface were reduced, the dispersion was improved, and the sintering agglomeration of SiO2 species was suppressed; The introduction of Si caused a large number of macroporous structures to be attached to the catalyst surface, which induced the rapid flow of active gases for the catalytic reaction; the interaction between Mn and Ce ions increased the rate of the reaction of NO to NO2. The ratio of Ce3+ to the adsorbed oxygen Oα was increased, which facilitated the The increased ratio of Ce3+ to adsorbed oxygen Oα promoted the oxygen migration and conversion ability of the catalyst, enhanced the adsorption of NH3, and improved the denitrification performance. (3) The 5%Mn/CePO4–15%SiO2 sample followed both the E-R mechanism and the l-H mechanism at the optimal denitrification temperature of 150°C. The increased content of Brønsted acidic sites and the increased stability of Lewis acidic sites resulted in an enhanced adsorption capacity of the catalyst for NH3. After the passage of NO+O2, the surface is enriched with nitrate and a large amount of NO2 is adsorbed, which promotes the catalyst to undergo the NH3-SCR reaction. The reacting species in the E-R mechanism are NO with NH4 + species and NH3 species, and the main reacting species in the L-H mechanism are bidentate nitrate and monodentate nitrate with NH4 + species adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites. coredata.dc:description: Preparation of low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts by Si and Mn modification and Si and Mn co-modification of CePO4 catalysts using mixed roasting and hydrothermal methods. XRD,BET,SEM and other characterisation tools were used to investigate the effect of Si and Mn modification on the catalyst structure. A series of different Si and Mn loadings and changes in catalyst denitrification performance, sulfur and water resistance after co-modification with Si and Mn were tested using NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and XPS, and the reaction pathways were investigated and the reaction mechanism of the catalysts was explored by FTIR detection in situ. The results show that CePO4-SiO2 catalyst at 250℃∼400℃, denitrification rate of about 90%; The optimum temperature for denitrification activity of the Mn/CePO4 catalyst was reduced, with a denitrification rate of 82% at 150℃; Mn/CePO4-SiO2 catalyst denitrification activity with significantly lower temperature and wider range. The denitrification rates of the catalysts were greater than 90% at 50℃∼300℃, with an optimum denitrification rate of 95 % at 150℃. The N2 selectivity of the catalyst is greater than 95 % in the low temperature range (below 200℃), good resistance to sulfur and water. The CePO4, SiO2 diffraction peaks on the surface of the sample decreased under the combined effect of Si and Mn. More acid sites appeared on the surface of the catalyst with elevated ratios of Ce3+ and adsorbed oxygen Oα, which promoted the catalyst's oxygen migration and conversion ability. After Si modification, the proportion of Mn4+ was significantly increased, which promoted the redox cycling of the catalyst in the low-temperature section. In situ IR results show that the catalyst follows both the Eley-Rideal mechanism and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism at 150℃. A variety of nitrate species produced by NO adsorption of the Si and Mn co-modified samples reacted rapidly with NH4 + species adsorbed at the Brønsted acid sites, which favoured the NH3-SCR reaction on the catalyst surface and improved the low-temperature denitrification efficiency.
coredata.dc:title: Performance and mechanism of low-temperature NH3-SCR denitrification over Mn/CePO4-SiO2 catalysts
